	<item>
				<title>About </title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/about/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 Feb 2014 02:44:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?page_id=2</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>About The Really Good Emails</h1>
<a href="http://matthewsmith.cc"><img class=" wp-image-440 alignleft" src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/profile-headshot-300x400.jpg" alt="portrait Matthew Smith" width="216" height="288" /></a>
<h2>Hi. I'm Matthew Smith</h2>
I like to speak up, sometimes too much, about things I like. It's why I started <a href="http://patterntap.com">PatternTap</a> back in the day and its why I have started Really Good Emails now  I love showing off other people's great design work.You can find me on Twitter as <a href="http://twitter.com/whale">@whale</a>
<div style="clear: both;"></div>
<a href="http://twitter.com/dideler"><img class=" wp-image-663 alignleft" src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/ptxMfmy-311x400.jpg" alt="ptxMfmy" width="218" height="280" /></a>
<h2>Dennis Ideler</h2>
I'm happy to have the help of Dennis Ideler. He's got great enthusiasm for emails along with me and will be adding to Really Good Emails regularly. Dennis is involved in the free and open source community, mainly with <a href="http://freeseer.github.com/">Freeseer</a> and <a href="http://softwareniagara.com/">Software Niagara</a>.You can find Dennis on Twitter as <a href="http://twitter.com/dideler">@dideler</a>
<div style="clear: both;"></div>
<a href="https://kellerdesignportfolio.wordpress.com/"><img class="size-full wp-image-685 alignleft" src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/chin.jpg" alt="chin" width="216" height="288" /></a>
<h2>Chin Pei Yee</h2>
Chin is a freelance designer based in Malaysia. She helps to collate the emails and post to ReallyGoodEmails.com. She's also got a good handle on getting things posted to Twitter. You can visit her site <a href="https://kellerdesignportfolio.wordpress.com/">Keller Design Portfolio</a>.
<div style="clear: both;"></div>
<h2>On Building</h2>
I built this site on a wordpress theme in about 30 hours. It's actually the last way I would want to build this, but it was an experiment in making a site as fast as humanly possible and getting value out of it. I'm stoked to call the site launched here on March 25, 2014. Well done Matthew, <a href="http://media2.giphy.com/media/Kc3FsPX7MWtsQ/200.gif">well done</a>.
<h2>Email Design Consulting</h2>
What's that? You're interested in learning more about your own email system strengths and weaknesses? That's funny, I'm available for consulting on your email situation. You should not trust me to grow your garden, I would kill things, but with product design  of which email is an integral part  you can learn from my successes and failures. I've worked on several product teams as <a href="http://zaarly.com">Creative Director</a>, <a href="http://relayfoods.com">Chief Creative Officer</a>, and Designer. All of these products use email marketing as a core part of their customer experience. <a title="Contact" href="http://reallygoodemails.com/contact/">Get in touch</a>, and let's powwow.
<ul>
	<li><strong style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: medium; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; letter-spacing: 0px; line-height: normal;">Email Review</strong><span style="letter-spacing: 0px;"> is done by email, and is $300 per reviewed email.</span></li>
	<li><strong style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: medium; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; letter-spacing: 0px; line-height: normal;">Email Design</strong><span style="letter-spacing: 0px;"> starts at $1000/email.</span></li>
</ul><!--more-->

<!--more-->
]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Retention Email Design from Mention</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/retention/retention-email-design-for-mention-net/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 08 Dec 2013 14:06:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.visualkicks.com/clipboard/standard/?p=62</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
This retention email from Mention.Net is simple and clear. By dividing the email into two spaces they maintain strong hierarchy of the content. The top is a clear call to action to keep your Mention product going. It may be a little long in the text, but the actual content is selling me on the value of their service. The bottom area is relaxed but visually appealing. The typography helps me read in order of importance. The images don't get in the way. Overall this email serves me the customer well by giving me a sense of what I need to do in order to stay with Mention, and the reasons why they believe I should do so.
<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The top area could use a lead in title to quickly explain the reason for the email. This is like saying Hi, I'm Matthew, and I'd like to explain why you'll benefit from the Mention Pro Plan. The top area is over using bold emphasis when a list might have been more helpful and easier to digest. The centered text on the top lacks the necessary padding on the sides to make the text feel more comfortable.
Pixel precision isn't what I think is important in an email. For instance the line-height (leading) is off on this email, but pointing it out is missing the point. The question is always: Is this email serving the customer and doing its job? Put another way: What would this email hire the customer to do for them?]]></content:encoded>

				<title>Contact</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/contact/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Dec 2013 16:27:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://demo.visualkicks.com/clipboard/standard/?page_id=123</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Well hey there.</h1>
What a great day it is to reach out and say hi. If you're reading this its either to congratulate me on making such a well-needed site for email inspiration, or possibly to heckle me with a diatribe on the merits of mustard based barbecue. I will accept either direction.

If you're interested in submitting your own emails for review, be aware that I'm quite picky, in fact many have said that I use picky as a euphemism for anal retentive ass-clown  this may or may not be true. Still, submit away! The best way to do this is actually to send the email to [email-obfuscate email="hello@reallygoodemails.com"]. Please include the original subject heading.

If you'd just like to say hey, or ask about sponsorship opportunities, you may do so below.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Newsletter</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 28 Feb 2014 18:18:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?page_id=199</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<link href="//cdn-images.mailchimp.com/embedcode/classic-081711.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
<div id="comment-form"><form class="formWrap" id="mc-embedded-subscribe-form" action="http://matthewsmith.us3.list-manage.com/subscribe/post?u=157259c43c41abe0d78c5c959&amp;id=c36aa218dc" method="post" name="mc-embedded-subscribe-form" novalidate="" target="_blank">
<h1>Email Newsletter</h1>
<p>You'll get email updates of really good emails. Yes, that is meta. But let's be honest, it's more like a meta cracker than a meta steak. Snack on that for a second while you fill out the form below.</p>
<!-- Name --> <input class="requiredField" id="mce-FNAME" type="text" name="FNAME" placeholder="Name" /><!-- Email --> <input class="requiredField email" id="mce-EMAIL" type="email" name="EMAIL" placeholder="Email Address" value="" />
<div class="clear" id="mce-responses"></div>
<!-- real people should not fill this in and expect good things - do not remove this or risk form bot signups-->
<div style="position: absolute; left: -5000px;"><input type="text" name="b_157259c43c41abe0d78c5c959_c36aa218dc" value="" /></div>
<div class="clear"></div>
<p class="form-submit"><input class="form-submit" id="mc-embedded-subscribe" type="submit" name="submit" value="Subscribe" /></p>

</form></div>
<script type="text/javascript">// < ![CDATA[
// < ![CDATA[
// < ![CDATA[ var fnames = new Array();var ftypes = new Array();fnames[0]='EMAIL';ftypes[0]='email';fnames[1]='FNAME';ftypes[1]='text'; try {     var jqueryLoaded=jQuery;     jqueryLoaded=true; } catch(err) {     var jqueryLoaded=false; } var head= document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0]; if (!jqueryLoaded) {     var script = document.createElement('script');     script.type = 'text/javascript';     script.src = '//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.4.4/jquery.min.js';     head.appendChild(script);     if (script.readyState && script.onload!==null){         script.onreadystatechange= function () {               if (this.readyState == 'complete') mce_preload_check();         }         } } var err_style = ''; try{     err_style = mc_custom_error_style; } catch(e){     err_style = '#mc_embed_signup input.mce_inline_error{border-color:#6B0505;} #mc_embed_signup div.mce_inline_error{margin: 0 0 1em 0; padding: 5px 10px; background-color:#6B0505; font-weight: bold; z-index: 1; color:#fff;}'; } var head= document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0]; var style= document.createElement('style'); style.type= 'text/css'; if (style.styleSheet) {   style.styleSheet.cssText = err_style; } else {   style.appendChild(document.createTextNode(err_style)); } head.appendChild(style); setTimeout('mce_preload_check();', 250); var mce_preload_checks = 0; function mce_preload_check(){     if (mce_preload_checks>40) return;
    mce_preload_checks++;
    try {
        var jqueryLoaded=jQuery;
    } catch(err) {
        setTimeout('mce_preload_check();', 250);
        return;
    }
    var script = document.createElement('script');
    script.type = 'text/javascript';
    script.src = 'http://downloads.mailchimp.com/js/jquery.form-n-validate.js';
    head.appendChild(script);
    try {
        var validatorLoaded=jQuery("#fake-form").validate({});
    } catch(err) {
        setTimeout('mce_preload_check();', 250);
        return;
    }
    mce_init_form();
}
function mce_init_form(){
    jQuery(document).ready( function($) {
      var options = { errorClass: 'mce_inline_error', errorElement: 'div', onkeyup: function(){}, onfocusout:function(){}, onblur:function(){}  };
      var mce_validator = $("#mc-embedded-subscribe-form").validate(options);
      $("#mc-embedded-subscribe-form").unbind('submit');//remove the validator so we can get into beforeSubmit on the ajaxform, which then calls the validator
      options = { url: 'http://matthewsmith.us3.list-manage1.com/subscribe/post-json?u=157259c43c41abe0d78c5c959&id=c36aa218dc&c=?', type: 'GET', dataType: 'json', contentType: "application/json; charset=utf-8",
                    beforeSubmit: function(){
                        $('#mce_tmp_error_msg').remove();
                        $('.datefield','#mc_embed_signup').each(
                            function(){
                                var txt = 'filled';
                                var fields = new Array();
                                var i = 0;
                                $(':text', this).each(
                                    function(){
                                        fields[i] = this;
                                        i++;
                                    });
                                $(':hidden', this).each(
                                    function(){
                                        var bday = false;
                                        if (fields.length == 2){
                                            bday = true;
                                            fields[2] = {'value':1970};//trick birthdays into having years
                                        }
                                    	if ( fields[0].value=='MM' && fields[1].value=='DD' && (fields[2].value=='YYYY' || (bday && fields[2].value==1970) ) ){
                                    		this.value = '';
									    } else if ( fields[0].value=='' && fields[1].value=='' && (fields[2].value=='' || (bday && fields[2].value==1970) ) ){
                                    		this.value = '';
									    } else {
									        if (/\[day\]/.test(fields[0].name)){
    	                                        this.value = fields[1].value+'/'+fields[0].value+'/'+fields[2].value;									        
									        } else {
    	                                        this.value = fields[0].value+'/'+fields[1].value+'/'+fields[2].value;
	                                        }
	                                    }
                                    });
                            });
                        $('.phonefield-us','#mc_embed_signup').each(
                            function(){
                                var fields = new Array();
                                var i = 0;
                                $(':text', this).each(
                                    function(){
                                        fields[i] = this;
                                        i++;
                                    });
                                $(':hidden', this).each(
                                    function(){
                                        if ( fields[0].value.length != 3 || fields[1].value.length!=3 || fields[2].value.length!=4 ){
                                    		this.value = '';
									    } else {
									        this.value = 'filled';
	                                    }
                                    });
                            });
                        return mce_validator.form();
                    }, 
                    success: mce_success_cb
                };
      $('#mc-embedded-subscribe-form').ajaxForm(options);

    });
}
function mce_success_cb(resp){
    $('#mce-success-response').hide();
    $('#mce-error-response').hide();
    if (resp.result=="success"){
        $('#mce-'+resp.result+'-response').show();
        $('#mce-'+resp.result+'-response').html(resp.msg);
        $('#mc-embedded-subscribe-form').each(function(){
            this.reset();
    	});
    } else {
        var index = -1;
        var msg;
        try {
            var parts = resp.msg.split(' - ',2);
            if (parts[1]==undefined){
                msg = resp.msg;
            } else {
                i = parseInt(parts[0]);
                if (i.toString() == parts[0]){
                    index = parts[0];
                    msg = parts[1];
                } else {
                    index = -1;
                    msg = resp.msg;
                }
            }
        } catch(e){
            index = -1;
            msg = resp.msg;
        }
        try{
            if (index== -1){
                $('#mce-'+resp.result+'-response').show();
                $('#mce-'+resp.result+'-response').html(msg);            
            } else {
                err_id = 'mce_tmp_error_msg';
                html = '



<div id="'+err_id+'" style="'+err_style+'"> '+msg+'</div>



';

                var input_id = '#mc_embed_signup';
                var f = $(input_id);
                if (ftypes[index]=='address'){
                    input_id = '#mce-'+fnames[index]+'-addr1';
                    f = $(input_id).parent().parent().get(0);
                } else if (ftypes[index]=='date'){
                    input_id = '#mce-'+fnames[index]+'-month';
                    f = $(input_id).parent().parent().get(0);
                } else {
                    input_id = '#mce-'+fnames[index];
                    f = $().parent(input_id).get(0);
                }
                if (f){
                    $(f).append(html);
                    $(input_id).focus();
                } else {
                    $('#mce-'+resp.result+'-response').show();
                    $('#mce-'+resp.result+'-response').html(msg);
                }
            }
        } catch(e){
            $('#mce-'+resp.result+'-response').show();
            $('#mce-'+resp.result+'-response').html(msg);
        }
    }
}
// ]]]]><![CDATA[></script>
<!--End mc_embed_signup-->]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>newsletter</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Alert Email Design from Lovely</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/alerts/alert-email-design-from-lovely/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 01 Mar 2014 18:45:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=259</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
This alert email from the apartment searching and rent payment product <a href="https://livelovely.com/">Lovely</a>is a great example of giving the customer what they need in a concise minimal format. I know exactly who the email is from and why I'm getting it. The content is all the things that help me know whether I want to follow up, and if so I know exactly what action to take.
<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
Aside from some tiny alignment issues the only thing I'd suggest as an improvement would be to make the language more human friendly. "You searched for Any Price - $1500, 3 Beds, Has Photos" could easily become "Alert for listings of 3 Bedroom apartments that rent for up to $1500/mo with photos." All these details take more time than you'd think, but they make the extra difference too.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Featured Product Email Design from Treehouse</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/featured-product/featured-product-email-design-from-treehouse/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 01 Mar 2014 19:30:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=263</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Treehouse emails have consistently been some of my favorites because of their scanability, large text for weak-eyed glasses wearing people like me, and great color scheme. This email is a great example of that.
<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
I think the headline here could use some activity. After I read <a href="http://www.amazon.com/To-Sell-Is-Human-Surprising/dp/1594631905">To Sell is Human</a> by Daniel Pink I began to pay more attention to email headlines as a kind of pitch. In this case, the fact that the Wordpress project is live is not that meaningful to me, where as if you told me that I could be a pro at wordpress sites in less than 15 hours I'd be all over it. See more on Pink's suggestion's on <a href="http://www.danpink.com/2013/06/how-to-pitch-better-the-email-pitch/">his site</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Transactional Email Design from Stripe</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/transactional/transactional-email-design-from-stripe/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 01 Mar 2014 19:45:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=268</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Receipt design is tough and this is a strong version that reads well in both desktop and mobile emails. For the Siteleaf transaction all the information I needed was here in this view.
<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The only thing I might add to something like this would be an option to print. Most of us will just print from the mail client, but sometimes a black and white printer friendly version is a more helpful thing to have for a receipt.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Customer Support Survey Email Design from Squarespace</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/support/customer-support-survey-email-design-from-squarespace/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 01 Mar 2014 19:59:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=274</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Squarespace uses a really tight color palette to keep their actions clear and focused. They also back up their image button with a link in case you're served an imageless version of the email. The use of the signature for the Squarespace Team is a nice touch that adds some personality.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
Their images could be sized to account for retina. That's getting picky though.
]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Email Newsletter Design from Charity: Water</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/email-newsletter-design-from-charity-water/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 01 Mar 2014 20:07:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=277</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Charity: Water's emails are always a real treat to get in the inbox. The photography in these emails is always beautiful and powerful. They do a great job of capturing the brand in their emails. The top of this email is not hard and rigid like many emails but has been designed with a feux watercolor edge to give a more gentle personal touch.

Further down the post the action button is actually really intriguing to me and I'd love to know how it converted, but it begs the question of the paragraph above if you didn't already read it. It asks me to follow up.
<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
If I didn't have images turned on I wouldn't necessarily know much about the sender or how to get in touch since the footer has the name of the organization removed, but this is minor I think since the from address and the subject contain information on Charity: Water.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Account Activation Email Design from MailChimp</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/activation/account-activation-email-design-from-mailchimp/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 01 Mar 2014 20:12:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=280</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Clear and to the point. MailChimp gets out of the way on this on an email that needs to be quick and clear.
<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
I wonder if "Just one more step..." is the right heading on an email that really needs me to activate my account. These kinds of choices can sometimes be brand driven or tested. The most important thing is to make sure the customer is clear about what to do.

<em>Note:The "username" title here was my username and I replaced it with default text for my own security</em>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Onboarding Security Email Design from Lovely</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/notice/onboarding-security-email-design-from-lovely/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 01 Mar 2014 20:19:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=283</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
As with other Lovely emails this is strong typographically and has good hierarchy. Its easy to browse and to read. The point of the email is clear.
<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
Imagery suggesting security or helping me understand the importance of this email would be helpful. In addition an opportunity to read more might be a good next step. The action item seems to be to "go to Lovely", but that doesn't seem like the best choice. Its hard to have emails like this and not freak people out or hurt your brand, but its also important to clearly communicate the importance of an issue like this.

They could use a little more padding on top and bottom in my pick opinion as well.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Retention Email Design from Squarespace</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/retention/retention-email-design-from-squarespace/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 01 Mar 2014 20:27:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=287</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
This retention email from Squarespace is great. It clearly lets me know that I have run out of time and only have a brief 24 hours to activate my account. It's clear and its a great way to keep me engaged. As with other Squarespace emails there is a clear call to action and an illustration of the product's benefits. The Squarespace team signature always adds extra personality. They always take care to make sure that any buttons that are images are backed up by links within the body of the text  smart.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The title could be more compelling. The fact that my free trial expires in 24 hours doesn't necessarily inspire me to get my ass in gear and do anything about it. That's a brand and testing issue though.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Retention-email-design-from-squarespace_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Retention-email-design-from-squarespace_Mobile-216x400.jpg" alt="Retention-email-design-from-squarespace_Mobile" width="216" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-879" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Subscription Email Design from Instapaper</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/email-digest/subscription-email-design-from-instapaper/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Mar 2014 13:47:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=299</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
I subscribed to Instapaper weekly for the express purpose of mining their other customer's most liked articles. I'm always looking for better, smarter, curation. This is a great pass at it. The design is typographically spot on and really helps me read through the article summaries quickly to know what I want to read more of. I hired this email with my time, and it is doing its job well. The actions on each article are clear but get out of the way. The inclusion of a photo is helpful in giving me context.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
I wouldn't mind a little social proof on these articles to see where they are coming from or how they ended up in my inbox. I like to know that if there is automation in play I can potentially adjust my behavior to inform a change in that automation. That's not happening here.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Featured Product Email Design from Everlane</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/featured-product/featured-product-email-design-from-everlane/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Mar 2014 13:54:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=302</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
I enjoy getting Everlane's products in my inbox for a couple of reasons. One is that I like watching their quality product line grow. I'm obsessively promotional about my <a href="https://www.everlane.com/collections/weekender-shop-mens">Everlane Weekender Bag</a> for instance. The other reason, and why its here on this site, is that the emails are always simple and to the point. When I get an email like this, I feel that Everlane believes I'm intelligent enough to not need a bunch of fluffy copy, but just the elemental picture that there is a great new product to be purchased. This makes me confident of them as a company and their product.

If I'm interested in more products I can easily click through the topic bar below the logotype on the top. In addition if I want to know one of their core principles of Radical Transparency, they include it on every email. Impressive.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
Not quite a weakness, but many companies don't have the opportunity to feature a solo product. This is the benefit of a small SKU shop. For a grocery store or a large ecommerce shop this is a different challenge.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[copy-of-subscription-email-design-from-instapaper]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Subscription Email Design from Tumblr</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/retention/subscription-email-design-from-tumblr/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Mar 2014 13:58:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=305</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Tumblr started sending these subscription emails sometime in 2013 as far as I can tell and it really elevated the sense of Tumblr as top-of-mind, which is difficult for any product to maintain. In that way, perhaps these could also be retention emails so I've categorized this both ways. The emails themselves do a great job of promoting the great photos or quotes that are the best of the people I follow on Tumblr. I hire these emails to keep me aware of what's happening in the Tumblr-sphere.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
I wonder if an email with thumbnails two wide could be more effective in giving me a taste of Tumblr and be able to show me more information? Pinterest pulls this off reasonably well.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Alert Email Design from Twitter</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/alerts/alert-email-design-from-twitter/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Mar 2014 14:05:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=308</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
This is one of the better emails I've seen from Twitter recently. Compelling imagery, clear title, simple copy, and a focused call to action. For an alert to take action, this emails serves the customer extremely well. It does all it promises and nothing more.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
Depending on who got this email it may have arrived in some inboxes with inexperienced Twitter customers. If my dad got this, he would have no idea how to follow Team USA. I'm hoping that the action on this button follows through for those customers and explains it well. Alternatively, they could have been just a little more explanatory here, but again its hard to know if that is on someone else's email that I didn't get.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Alert Email Design from Dropbox</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/alerts/alert-email-design-from-dropbox/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Mar 2014 14:08:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=311</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Sometimes its necessary to send an email that's like a memo. A quick update that may just be informational and not require any action. Dropbox has done a great job of doing that here in this email. It's clear who the email is from and why its being sent.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
Personally I like a little humor or humanity in an email like this. I love seeing when people don't take themselves too seriously. Maybe a link to a gif, or something beautiful because when you read the news its nice to see something that makes you happy.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Subscription Email Design from Digg</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/email-digest/subscription-email-design-from-digg/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Mar 2014 18:54:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=314</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
I subscribed to these news.me emails for the purpose of getting relevant news from the people I follow in my industry. The email more than adequately serves the purpose I hired it for. I get a quick view of news that has risen to the top with my Twitter followers. The sections and titles are clear with the blue link color helping me scan easily. The use of social proof giving me context for the articles is valuable to help me decide what to read.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
Looks like there's a missing asset file where my profile avatar should be. Otherwise, I think it accomplishes everything I need from it.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>314</wp:post_id>

		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>subscription-email-design-from-digg</wp:post_name>

		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="digg"><![CDATA[Digg]]></category>

	<item>
				<title>Featured Product Email Design from Lyst</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/featured-product/featured-product-email-design-from-lyst/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Mar 2014 19:15:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=317</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Lyst is an interesting service where I can get updates on products that I like or want to see more of. In this case I get an update on when an item is back in stock or on sale. There is a lot of information here in this email but the use of clear typography and hierarchy in this email is what makes it work.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
There's too much information in the footer that hasn't been culled down to be meaningful for a customer. It all feels like legalese.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Contributor Email Design from Squarespace</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/transactional/contributor-email-design-from-squarespace/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Mar 2014 20:08:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=324</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
This email is succinct  I like that. I know what I need to do if I choose to. The typography, hierarchy and flow are clear and lack nothing in my opinion. The addition of the "handmade in New York" is a nice touch in the footer giving the product a sense of craftsmanship and geography. 

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
Compared to other Squarespace emails this one has a slightly different layout and a unique action color, but without good reason. It can be tough to pull all your emails together into a tight grouping but it goes a long way in being a consistent part of the product.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Email Newsletter Design from Squarespace</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/email-newsletter-design-from-squarespace/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Mar 2014 20:24:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=327</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
One of the things you can count on from the Squarespace team is a radical attention to simplicity. You can tell they have said no to more than they've said yes to. It's these constraints that make their emails easy to review, read and feel served by. They also curate the number of emails they send out. I never feel bothered by them. In this case a newsletter only comes about once a month or so. Infrequent but relevant. Well done.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
I'm just not a negative guy. I see nothing wrong here so why hunt for it. Instead look at <a href="http://media2.giphy.com/media/QgNmsslvY5uLK/200.gif">cats</a>.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>email-newsletter-design-from-squarespace</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
				<title>Email Newsletter Design from 500px</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/email-newsletter-design-from-500px/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Mar 2014 13:54:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=331</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
500px uses a strong grid and a great use of its most powerful asset  great imagery, to really entice you to dig into their newsletter. Newsletters can be used to keep your application top of mind, or to give customers an incite into what's happening on or in the product. In this case 500px is showcasing some of the best photographs that have recently been uploaded as well as giving you a meaningful insight into the resource they are with tutorials. This is a useful email. Usefulness is a big win in my book.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
I think they could use white space or dividing lines to better divide the sections. In addition they could tighten up the margin's under headlines that are currently just deep enough to cause a slight lack of connectedness between headlines and the content they are headlining.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Email-newsletter-design-from-500px_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Email-newsletter-design-from-500px_Mobile-207x1024.jpg" alt="Email-newsletter-design-from-500px_Mobile" width="207" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-874" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Email Newsletter Design from Etsy</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/email-newsletter-design-from-etsy/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Mar 2014 14:12:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=373</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
I'm a big fan of Etsy's product design, not the aesthetics necessarily mind you, but the design  the whole of the product and the ethic and utility behind it. This newsletter was a welcome surprise in my inbox recently. It was like a mini browsing of what's new on Etsy and some of the great new products people are selling or putting in collections. The mixed gris is executed flawlessly here with clear linkable headings so I can jump off and get right into the web or mobile product. They have carefully chose the arrangement of items to sell the best of Etsy. The effect is that I think Etsy is doing well and the product lines are getting ever better  whether or not that is actually the case  impressions can be everything.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
I'm not entirely sure what these bars of photos are without titles. Knowing the way those folks test things I bet its just a way to see if people click on things with or without titles more :D

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Email-newsletter-design-from-etsy_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Email-newsletter-design-from-etsy_Mobile-383x1024.jpg" alt="Email-newsletter-design-from-etsy_Mobile" width="383" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-871" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Email Newsletter Design from Emma</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/email-newsletter-design-from-emma/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Mar 2014 14:19:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=376</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
These designer series from Invision are always fun to get in the inbox and see who's out there designing. I actually love seeing their faces. I think at some point they had them covered. I wonder what happened to the click rate when seeing faces  that would be fun data to analyze. The emails are typographically strong, colorful, and have a clear call to action. I do love how short and to the point they are as well. This is just a note to say we have a lot more for you to read and enjoy on our site. Only the most important information needed is on this email.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The type on part these emails is likely way too small for mobile. My guess is they are working on responsive email designs as we speak :D

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Email-newsletter-design-from-emma_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Email-newsletter-design-from-emma_Mobile-233x400.jpg" alt="Email-newsletter-design-from-emma_Mobile" width="233" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-868" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Email Newsletter Design from Pinterest</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/email-newsletter-design-from-pinterest/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Mar 2014 14:23:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=379</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Great updates to keep the Pinterest things I'm interested in top of mind. This is a curated list based the pins I have liked or put in boards. It serves me well and keeps my interest on Pinterest as a tool for collecting things I like or communicating things I like to others.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
They may have made the title of my board explicit at the top so that I knew immediately it was for my workspace board. Otherwise, these are strong emails and serve me well as a Pinterest customer.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Email-newsletter-design-from-pinterest_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Email-newsletter-design-from-pinterest_Mobile-309x1024.jpg" alt="Email-newsletter-design-from-pinterest_Mobile" width="309" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-865" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Share Request Email Design from Dropbox</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/transactional/share-request-email-design-from-dropbox/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 12 Mar 2014 17:39:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=384</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Keep it simple stupid. Dropbox does a great job of making the main thing, the main thing. The action here is clear, and the messaging is tight. The use of the boundary box to keep the message contained and feel professional is helpful and unobtrusive. There's even a little tidbit of emotion with Enjoy! that I think adds just the right amount of human touch.
<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
Maybe they could add a signature like Squarespace does to their team signoff, but otherwise this is a great email.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Comment Update Email Design from Medium</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/transactional/comment-update-email-design-from-medium/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 12 Mar 2014 18:08:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=388</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Medium has really nailed these emails making them align well with their product and giving a clear sense of what needs to be done. There is absolutely no more than is necessary in this email. The brand is clear, the interface gets out of the way, and the supplementary actions are evident but unobtrusive.]]></content:encoded>

				<title>Onboarding Email Design from Flow</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/onboarding/onboarding-email-design-from-flow/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 17 Mar 2014 14:30:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[whale]]></dc:creator>

	<item>
				<title>Direct Message Email Design From Twitter</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/transactional/direct-message-email-design-from-twitter/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Mar 2014 01:40:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=402</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Twitters transactional emails are right on brand. They feel like a part of the product as though you really never left the app  for the most part. All the important content is clear is available and to the point. The Message action button takes me directly into a message at<a href="http://twitter.com/" target="_blank">twitter.com</a>with the field focused.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
There may be more information here or more visual noise than is really necessary. There are at least three shades of gray and at a glance around 5 or 6 different uses of helvetica sizes and weights and colors. More than is absolutely necessary.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Direct-message-email-design-from-twitter_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Direct-message-email-design-from-twitter_Mobile-150x102.jpg" alt="Direct-message-email-design-from-twitter_Mobile" width="150" height="102" class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-861" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Invitation Email From Slack</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/welcome/invitation-email-from-slack/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Mar 2014 01:42:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=405</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Nice big readable type in an email is one of my favorite characteristics of a great product email. Its good for mobile and frankly I think its good for web most of the time too. Though Im not often a fan of wide open uncontained email designs I think this one is working.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The typography here could use a little bit of hierarchy to come through more clearly. Headings rather than just bold, and maybe a slightly lighter color for the body copy. Scannability of the hierarchy of typography aids in faster perception of whats being said or communicated in an email. Due to the brevity of the email I also think the sec on button is a bit redundant.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Invitation-email-from-slack_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Invitation-email-from-slack_Mobile-238x400.jpg" alt="Invitation-email-from-slack_Mobile" width="238" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-859" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Product Update Email Design from Gibbon</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/product-update-email-design-from-gibbon/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 22 Mar 2014 02:51:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=408</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
These emails from Gibbon are the cats meow. The imagery of the books is all stacked up gives you a great feeling of learning and lots of new content. The introduction title and copy are all very clear and simple. This email gets out of the way and lets you dig into the content you signed up to see from Gibbon. The actions on the email are straightforward. I know exactly what I should do if I want to dig deeper.

They even add a sharing option in the bottom of the email that indicates what youll be sharing which, Id guess, would increase the conversion to sharing much higher. Its less risk.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The imagery isnt retina level, but then again, neither are all of the images on ReallyGoodEmails! Ha. Theres always something to improve.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Product-update-email-design-from-gibbon_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Product-update-email-design-from-gibbon_Mobile-335x1024.jpg" alt="Product-update-email-design-from-gibbon_Mobile" width="335" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-856" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>408</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>

	<item>
				<title>Product Feature Email Design from DesignModo</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/product-update/product-feature-email-design-from-designmodo/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Mar 2014 01:55:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=413</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
This is a bold easy to look at email. By using big solid colors instead of a typical white background DeisgnModo is giving us something unique to set apart their featured product  Generator. The typography is easy to scan and large enough to say it has a mobile focus.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The action or focus of the email is likely below the fold. While the fold is not as important as it once was its still important to engage your customer with the reason they would hire your email before they are required or enticed to scroll.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Product-feature-email-design-from-designmodo_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Product-feature-email-design-from-designmodo_Mobile-247x1024.jpg" alt="Product-feature-email-design-from-designmodo_Mobile" width="247" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-853" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Newsletter Email Design from BigCartel</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/newsletter-email-design-from-bigcartel/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Mar 2014 02:04:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=416</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Ive always appreciated these well crafted emails form BigCartel. They use a water paper effect at the top of the email design that relaxes the strong grid in the rest of the design. The typography is impeccable with clear hierarchy and great use of the grid. Ive always liked how they use thumbnails on the side of their newsletter to give some visual information about each block of content.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
Its time for a mobile update. These emails are nearly impossible to read on a phone as the text is the size of baby mouse poop  or something like that.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Newsletter-email-design-from-bigcartel_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Newsletter-email-design-from-bigcartel_Mobile-158x400.jpg" alt="Newsletter-email-design-from-bigcartel_Mobile" width="158" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-848" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Retention Email Design from MailChimp</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/retention/retention-email-design-from-mailchimp/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Mar 2014 02:11:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=419</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
This onboarding/retention email from MailChimp is a great example of how dead simple but helpful an email can be. Helpfulness is often overlooked in favor of either visual appeal or overloading an email with glittery links. If Im a new customer and Im trying to get into MailChimp this is a great way to keep me invested and give me the help I need to take those first steps.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
You could maybe argue that the logo should be the version with the logotype included for better recognition from the customer, but the email subject does include their name, so that may not be necessary. Id love to see MailChimp spruce these up with a tad of color as they do on their site, I think it adds a lot of warmth over the grey and white.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Retention-email-design-from-mailchimp_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Retention-email-design-from-mailchimp_Mobile-200x400.jpg" alt="Retention-email-design-from-mailchimp_Mobile" width="200" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-845" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>419</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-03-23 22:11:30</wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>

	<item>
				<title>Featured Product Email Design from Charity:Water</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/product-update/featured-product-email-design-from-charitywater/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Mar 2014 02:16:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=422</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Great imagery that brings me into the email quickly. Im curious about Pipeline right from the beginning. The header gives me an indication that its News from Charity:Water which I find helpful. Context can be a great small value add to an email like this.

The headlines and copy is to the point and clear. The action is bold and strong and inviting. As with others of their emails they modify the top of the email visually to get away from the oft-blocky feel of email newsletters. Its a very nice touch.

Unsubscribe is clear and bold in the bottom. I love when companies are confident enough in their product that they make this a service to customers. Well done yall.

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Featured-product-email-design-from-charitywater_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Featured-product-email-design-from-charitywater_Mobile-186x400.jpg" alt="Featured-product-email-design-from-charitywater_Mobile" width="186" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-842" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Update Email Design from Medium</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/product-update/update-email-design-from-medium/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Mar 2014 02:24:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=425</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
I hire these emails to give me the best of Medium each week and they do exactly that. The typography is relaxing and easy to read and gives me just enough to dive into the Medium article. Photography on the featured article helps give it prominence. I know exactly what I should do with this email if I want to follow up on any of these articles.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The double stacked horizontal lines for the headers feel a little hectic and noisy compared to the rest of the design. I think they could be single lines and maybe dimmed to a lighter grey to help distract less.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Update-email-design-from-medium_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Update-email-design-from-medium_Mobile-114x1024.jpg" alt="Update-email-design-from-medium_Mobile" width="114" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-839" /></a>
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Featured Product Sale Email Design from Square Market</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/product-update/featured-product-sale-email-design-from-square-market/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Mar 2014 02:32:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=428</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A nice redesign from Square Markets previously attractive emails. This one features a header with quick links to different areas of the marketplace. My guess is that they wanted to start seeing higher conversion in these emails, and yet theyre experimenting with ways to do that while maintaining a relaxing and peaceful ethic of design. Smart.

These emails are also amazingly responsive for mobile devices. They are laid out wonderfully on a mobile device and the text is totally readable without being overly large.

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Featured-product-sale-email-design-from-square-market_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Featured-product-sale-email-design-from-square-market_Mobile-165x1024.jpg" alt="Featured-product-sale-email-design-from-square-market_Mobile" width="165" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-850" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Alert Email Design from Rdio</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/alerts/alert-email-design-from-rdio/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 25 Mar 2014 01:54:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=433</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Its nice to know when someone likes youre playlist and this is exactly what this email tells me, simply, and then gets out of the way. It reminds me of what my playlist includes by including the album art that makes up the playlist. Theres very little to this email, and thats the way it should be.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The switch in justification from left aligned logo to center aligned content feels off to me. Perhaps its just the lack of something balancing the logo on the right side? In addition the legal and subscription text below the nav links in the light blue footer feel overly lengthy and much of it feels unneeded.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Alert-email-design-from-rdio_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Alert-email-design-from-rdio_Mobile-162x400.jpg" alt="Alert-email-design-from-rdio_Mobile" width="162" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-836" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Newsletter Email Design from HackDesign</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/newsletter-email-design-from-hackdesign/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 25 Mar 2014 02:04:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=436</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HackDesign has done a great job of making design into lessons via email. Theres a lot to love about this. Theyve made a compelling email here with very little involved beyond typography. This is a great example of using color, size, and whitespace to achieve a really scannable space of information.

The babyblue callout for the authors is a great way to set that space apart and give us a human connection with a picture. Overall a great email that serves the precise purpose I hired it for, to forward to people I want to learn design, HA!

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Newsletter-email-design-from-hackdesign_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Newsletter-email-design-from-hackdesign_Mobile-89x1024.jpg" alt="Newsletter-email-design-from-hackdesign_Mobile" width="89" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-832" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Product Update Email Design from Pinterest</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/product-update/product-update-email-design-from-pinterest/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 26 Mar 2014 04:10:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=447</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I was happy to see this email show up in my inbox this morning. My friend Chris Merritt (link:<a href="http://chrismerritt.cc/" target="_blank">http://ChrisMerritt.cc</a>) sent me his great board on container homes. I get to see a preview of the board beautifully layer out, and the heart of the email is friendly and fun. This is actually an incredibly complex email to build with a stack of images, but Pinterest has really pulled it off. Great hierarchy, great brand continuity. This is a perfect example of how integrated email is into the product itself.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Product-update-email-design-from-pinterest_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Product-update-email-design-from-pinterest_Mobile-235x400.jpg" alt="Product-update-email-design-from-pinterest_Mobile" width="235" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-828" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Featured Product Email Design from Icebergs</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/featured-product/featured-product-email-design-from-icebergs/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 26 Mar 2014 04:20:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=450</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Icebergs is promoting their Chrome extension with this email. Its clear, on brand and beautiful. Lots of whitespace makes the imagery appear important and interesting. The action on this email has the right hierarchy, its clear and to the point. The contextual links in the footer are styled uniquely to set them apart and they are a great way to help me dig into the Icebergs product quickly<span style="font-size: 15px; letter-spacing: 0px; line-height: 1.6;">.</span>
<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The space between the top grey slim header and the main white box is tight, and text should always be aligned vertically with the capital letters being the portion of the text to center.
<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Icebergs_mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Icebergs_mobile-379x1024.jpg" alt="Icebergs_mobile" width="379" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-673" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>450</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-03-26 00:20:20</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-03-26 04:20:20</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>featured-product-email-design-from-icebergs</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="featured-product"><![CDATA[Featured Product]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="icebergs"><![CDATA[Icebergs]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wpas_done_all</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>vk_post_title</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[on]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>Email Newsletter Design from Icebergs</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/email-newsletter-design-from-icebergs/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 26 Mar 2014 04:26:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=453</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
A great use of an animated gif from Icebergs. The<a href="https://s3.amazonaws.com/icebergs.static/newsletter/newsletter_7/img/screenshot@2x.gif" target="_blank">main illustration</a>here in the center is animated to show the screenshot process. Animated gifs can be fun, but should only ever be used for secondary communication purposes, not for a main point of the email. Images are still often not shown in email campaigns.

The Web Plugin for Icebergs is their strongest point of contact to onboard new customers and so they highlight it by putting it in a high contrast dark footer with a bold blue button. Smart move. The image floated to the right is also a helpful way of showing them more about what the plugin can do for them.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The typography is a little small on mobile devices and a better responsive solution should be looked at. Also, as stated in other posts on Iceberg, the top grey thin header is a little too tight next to the main white content box, and the text within it feels bottom heavy.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Email-newsletter-design-from-icebergs_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Email-newsletter-design-from-icebergs_Mobile-258x1024.jpg" alt="Email-newsletter-design-from-icebergs_Mobile" width="258" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-825" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Newsletter Email Design from Campaign Monitor</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/newsletter-email-design-from-campaign-monitor/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 27 Mar 2014 02:38:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=459</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
Full width display of beautiful colors and impeccable typography make this a really attractive email right off the bat. The<a href="http://i4.createsend1.com/ei/y/C5/D13/47D/184626/images/hero.gif" target="_blank">animated gif</a>in the main email content is a great touch that is fun, but doesnt distract from the primary action<span style="font-size: 15px; letter-spacing: 0px; line-height: 1.6;">.</span>
<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The icons didnt come through in the social buttons and the bottom darkest background feels like one level of complexity too much. Is a different background color needed there, is the texture needed? Im always asking what would the customer hire this aesthetic to do for them? In this case, maybe you could argue for distinction or separation of content, but I think it could have been achieved more simply.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Newsletter-Email-Design-from-Campaign-Monitor_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Newsletter-Email-Design-from-Campaign-Monitor_Mobile-344x1024.jpg" alt="Newsletter-Email-Design-from-Campaign-Monitor_Mobile" width="344" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-809" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>New Article Email Design from Explore Create Repeat</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/new-article/new-article-email-design-from-explore-create-repeat/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 27 Mar 2014 02:42:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=462</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Bold simple layout, beautiful attractive imagery, and effective follow up action. A great email that follows some interesting conventions that mimic some of iOS7s full width flat design.

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/New-Article-Email-Design-from-Explore-Create-Repeat_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/New-Article-Email-Design-from-Explore-Create-Repeat_Mobile-214x400.jpg" alt="New-Article-Email-Design-from-Explore-Create-Repeat_Mobile" width="214" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-805" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Account Verification Email Design from Stacks</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/activation/account-activation-email-design-from-stacks/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 27 Mar 2014 03:08:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=469</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Account verification emails are often like first impressions. This one gets out of the way and gets you back to the product quickly. Sometimes its nice to add a little personality to these emails but it can depend on the brand if thats appropriate.

<h3>Strengths</h3>
The email is perfectly simple, and has no extra fluff.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The typography could be spaced better so that youre not doing the long jump between title and body copy and action, etc. Leave the olympics to the athletes.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Account-Verification-Email-Design-from-Stacks_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Account-Verification-Email-Design-from-Stacks_Mobile-367x400.jpg" alt="Account-Verification-Email-Design-from-Stacks_Mobile" width="367" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-803" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Product Update Email Design from Flipboard</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/product-update-email-design-from-flipboard/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 27 Mar 2014 03:50:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=479</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Strengths</h3>
FlipBoard has done a great job giving me some insight into the latest available on the site. The brand is clear, and the typography makes this a quickly scannable email. The images pull me in emotionally and the magazine sections get me to the content that I want quickly.
<h3>Weaknesses</h3>
The action links under the magazines are super tight up next to the bottom of the images and arent called out well. They should be clearer and have more breathing room.

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Product-Update-Email-Design-from-Flipboard_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Product-Update-Email-Design-from-Flipboard_Mobile-132x1024.jpg" alt="Product-Update-Email-Design-from-Flipboard_Mobile" width="132" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-799" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Product Update Email Design from GoSquared</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/product-update-email-design-from-gosquared/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 27 Mar 2014 03:55:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=482</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Outstanding simplicity in this product update email design. I love how simple every line is and the chunks of information are exactly what Id expect to see to help me know if GoSquared continues to be a good analytics fit for me. The repeated action is also a great idea to increase conversion opportunities, and of course, serve the customer.

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Product-Update-Email-Design-from-GoSquared_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Product-Update-Email-Design-from-GoSquared_Mobile-373x1024.jpg" alt="Product-Update-Email-Design-from-GoSquared_Mobile" width="373" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-797" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Retention Progress Email Design from Treehouse</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/retention/retention-progress-email-design-from-treehouse/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 27 Mar 2014 04:01:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When youre working through a coding project on Treehouse you want to know how youre doing and Treehouse wants to keep you motivated and engaged as a customer. Using a retention email like this can be a great way to help your customers keep your product top of mind. As usual these emails are impeccably designed with great attention to detail.

Hi hello82, please confirm your FindTheBest account

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Account-Activation-Email-Design-from-FindTheBest_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Account-Activation-Email-Design-from-FindTheBest_Mobile-480x266.jpg" alt="Account-Activation-Email-Design-from-FindTheBest_Mobile" width="480" height="266" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-786" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>

	<item>
				<title>New Activity Alert Email Design from Dropbox</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/alerts/new-activity-alert-email-design-from-dropbox/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 07 Apr 2014 08:54:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=568</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
You've linked a new computer to Dropbox

	<item>
				<title>Alert Email Design from Lift</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/transactional/alert-email-design-from-lift/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Apr 2014 02:37:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=653</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Email Subject</h3>
Yesterday you checked into 1 goal. What can you do today?

<h3>Mobile Email View</h3>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Alert-Email-Design-from-Lift_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Alert-Email-Design-from-Lift_Mobile-245x400.jpg" alt="Alert-Email-Design-from-Lift_Mobile" width="245" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-726" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

Simple design. Focused on one thing, your progress. The email can easily be read within 30 seconds.

Solid email subject. Contains a personal summary and a motivational message to continue making progress towards your goal.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

I'm left with the impression that it was designed mobile-first, as the mobile version looks better than the desktop version. The desktop version appears incomplete because of the poor use of white space.

The header and footer are slightly difficult to read (especially on mobile), because of the low-contrast font colour; grey on grey harms readability.

There's some minor inconsistencies between the desktop and mobile versions, such as the font colour for the greeting.

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>alert-email-design-from-lift</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
