	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Article Recommendation Email Design from Medium</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/alerts/article-recommendation-email-design-from-medium/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Apr 2014 02:43:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=656</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
Time Management was recommended by Julius Koroll

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Article-Recommendation-Email-Design-from-Medium_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Article-Recommendation-Email-Design-from-Medium_Mobile-297x400.jpg" alt="Article-Recommendation-Email-Design-from-Medium_Mobile" width="297" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-721" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

Medium does a great job at keeping this email simple, short, and to the point. The minimalism and excellent use of negative space are key in this uncluttered design, making it easy to find the content you care about.

You're more likely to read a story if it's been personally recommended. The profile photo combined with the name quickly reminds you that the recommendation is by someone you know.

The footer is concise and doesn't distract. The less important text has lower contrast, helping the important links to stand out.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

Bolding the "recommended" text behind the recommender's name may be unnecessary and causes some of the emphasis on the name to be lost.

The title of the story contains a line break, which is unusual as titles are typically not wrapped. Consider starting the title on a new line.

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Update Email Design from Peak</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/announcement/update-email-design-from-peak/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Apr 2014 02:52:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=659</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
We're waging war on shoulder taps

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Update-Email-Design-from-Peak_Mobile1.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Update-Email-Design-from-Peak_Mobile1-327x1024.jpg" alt="Update-Email-Design-from-Peak_Mobile" width="327" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-719" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

The banner does a great job at summarizing the product. If someone were to glance at the email, they would still get the message just by viewing the banner. Bonus points if it's clickable.

The content is very readable, thanks to a sans-serif font, high contrast, short paragraphs, and proper line spacing.

The wording is simple. The text clearly communicates what problem the product solves.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

Make the product look luxurious by using the "less is more" principle. Not much content is needed to communicate the general idea of the product or service advertised.

The introduction can be trimmed down. For example, the first paragraph can be reduced to

<blockquote>
For the past year, we've been working on a beautiful new product called Peak. Today we're excited to share it with the world.
</blockquote>

The section below the call to action button ("About Peak") doesn't add much value and makes the email too long. It contains a lot of repeated information from the first sectionsome sentences are copied verbatim. It would have been better as a blog post.

The links could have had their underlines removed to increase legibility. But people expect links to to be underlined, so they should still show when hovered over with the mouse.

It's unclear who the company is behind the product. With such a common name as Peak, it's extra important to tell readers who made it so they (or those they tell about the product) can get meaningful results when searching for it later.

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Event Promotion Email Design from Litmus</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/promotion/event-promotion-email-design-from-litmus/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 18 Apr 2014 10:26:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=811</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
Save the date: The Email Design Conference 2014

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Event-Promotion-Email-Design-from-Litmus_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Event-Promotion-Email-Design-from-Litmus_Mobile-328x1024.jpg" alt="Event-Promotion-Email-Design-from-Litmus_Mobile" width="328" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-813" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

Contains some of the most important information above the fold: what, when, and where. This section is quick and easy to read. Icons help identify the type of information.

Below the fold are two more sections. The middle section provides more details about the event, such as a brief description and a rough outline.

The last section contains a short video of highlights from the previous conference. Videos are great in addition to text. Video is easy to understand and people instantly emotionally engage with it in a way they don't often do with text and static images. The play button on top of the thumbnail image makes it obvious that it's a video. The thumbnail gives the impression that the video is already loaded.

Notice how the email is split into three sectionseach with a different background colourto explain the topic in stages. This improves readability by providing structure. Just like paragraphs, each section should deal with one idea. Short sections make the content look inviting, whereas a long chunk can discourage people from even starting to read.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

The goal of the email is clear (i.e. inform the public about the conference), but the call to action is unclear. It appears to be sharing the news on Twitter, but that doesn't nearly provide as much value to the reader as it does to the conference.

As a conference goer, I want to know how much it will cost to attend. That info isn't available. There may be a good reason behind this; perhaps A/B tests indicate that revealing the price later in the sales funnel gives better results. I also want to be able to purchase a ticket. If tickets are not available now, let me pre-order, or tell me when they'll be available.

The first text that appears in the email is a bit odd: "Trust us: view this email in Apple Mail or the web version in Chrome/Safari." Besides the trust issues, why do they assume recipients run OS X, and is Firefox no longer a modern web browser? This sentence will likely appear as the snippet text, that is, the text that appears next to the email subject in the preview. It's a useless snippet because it tells you nothing about the contents of the email. A good snippet can improve open rates.

The layout of the schedule for the third day (middle section) is inconsistent with the other days. The table is twice as long and breaks the bottom alignment with the two tables on its left, giving a messy appearance and causing confusion. Will the third day be twice as long?

The mobile version is the exact same email. All that info crammed into a small screen results in a cluttered design. Some of the content also becomes difficult to read because of the small font.

The email is a bit lengthy. It might have been better to split the content into several emails. Each section could have been its own email, spread out over a few days. And each email would contain a call to action, which would be to register for the conference.

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key>_wpas_skip_6468195</wp:meta_key>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Transactional Friend Email Design from Facebook</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/transactional/transactional-friend-email-design-from-facebook/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Apr 2014 08:44:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=895</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
Your friend wants you to check out Gorillabunny on Facebook

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Transactional-Friend-Email-Design-from-Facebook_Mobile1.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Transactional-Friend-Email-Design-from-Facebook_Mobile1-480x391.jpg" alt="Transactional-Friend-Email-Design-from-Facebook_Mobile" width="480" height="391" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-917" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

The email is short and simple. I can see who invited me, what they invited me to like, and I can like it straight from the email. Since I'm thinking about invites, I can also easily view all my invites. 

The primary actions stand out due to their strong background colour.

The branding is consistent with Facebook's branding. The famous Facebook blue and the thumbs up are used.

More links lead to more clicks, and this email has a ton of links.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

The email subject could have been more personalized; "Your friend" would be replaced with your friend's name. I imagine this would improve open rates, but Facebook should know best if they are running A/B tests.

Some more information about the company (or whatever you're invited to like) would be useful. For example, a short description, or how many likes they have. Anything to give me more reason to like them.

The placement of the "Like" button seems out of place, it's very far from the rest of the content. It's possible that this is a strength, as putting the call to action in its own space makes it stand out more.

The header can be reduced to just the Facebook logo. "Invites from Friends" doesn't add much value.

The greeting and signature adds more content than is necessary for a notification email. Consider only using them for emails that actually come from the Facebook team (e.g. announcements of new features, or changes to the privacy policy). Though including them does make the email more courteous.

The footer is a bit cluttered. Is it really necessary to indicate who the message was sent to? As the recipient, that should be obvious.

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_key>_thumbnail_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[896]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Password Reset Email from Instagram</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/transactional/password-reset-email/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Apr 2014 08:46:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=899</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
Reset Your Password

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Password-Reset-Email_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Password-Reset-Email_Mobile-240x400.jpg" alt="Password-Reset-Email_Mobile" width="240" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-900" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

This is a great example of keeping it simple. The interface is made as simple as possible by eliminating anything that may potentially confuse the reader.

The language is helpful and personal. It reads like it was written by a human. You'd be surprised how many emails do a poor job at this.

White space is used really well, especially for the call to action in the centre. All attention is drawn to that button. The goal is to reset your password, and this design makes that very obvious.

To better appreciate the design of this password reset email, take a look at this one by eBay.

<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/ebay-password-reset.png"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/ebay-password-reset.png" alt="ebay-password-reset" /></a>

Critiquing it would take another post. But notice how cluttered and disorganized it is. Granted, eBay is a marketplace and so there are more challenges when designing such an email. Still, there's lots of room for improvement. 

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

Not many, and the weaknesses that do exist are very minor.

It's unclear what exactly will happen if you click on the "Reset Password" button. Will it bring you to a page where you get to enter a new password? Will you be emailed a new temporary password?

There's some inconsistent wording; it mentions resetting and changing the password.

The majority of the sentences start with "If". It's too repetitive, mix it up a bit. For example, "If you ignore this message, your password won't be changed." can be rewritten as "Your password won't be changed if you ignore this message", or "Ignore this message to keep your current password."

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Weekly Newsletter Email Design from CopyBlogger</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/newsletter/weekly-newsletter-email-design-from-copyblogger/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 26 Apr 2014 13:41:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=930</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>

	<item>
				<title>Bold Promotional Product Sale Email Design from Solo Project Management</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/promotion/bold-promotional-email-design-from-solo-project-management/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Apr 2014 09:14:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=973</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
Still time for a Solo Summer

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Bold-Promotional-Product-Sale-Email-Design-from-Solo_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Bold-Promotional-Product-Sale-Email-Design-from-Solo_Mobile-352x1024.jpg" alt="Bold-Promotional-Product-Sale-Email-Design-from-Solo_Mobile" width="352" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-974" /></a>

<h2>Strengths</h2>
This is a bold email design that hopes for drama to make the customer click through. The sale is large and the imagery is appealing. Id be really interested in knowing more about the conversion rates and its effect on customers.

<h2>Weaknesses</h2>
The call to action is weak. Its not entirely clear where to click though the audience is likely web savvy enough to just look for a mouse pointer.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Product Update Email Design from Layer Vault</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/product-update/product-update-email-design-from-layer-vault/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Apr 2014 09:20:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=977</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
Introducing LayerVault Enterprise

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Introducing-LayerVault-Enterprise_Mobile.jpg"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Introducing-LayerVault-Enterprise_Mobile-172x400.jpg" alt="Introducing-LayerVault-Enterprise_Mobile" width="172" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-979" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

This email is outstanding. No clutter and incredibly concise. Simple wording describes the new product, no jargon.

The layout is nicely formatted, including the footer. High contrast text improves readability. The primary call to action stands out.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

What the heck is LayerVault? The email fails to tell me that. I could have signed up a year ago and never used your site, I'm clueless now. Describe what the product is <strong>every time you communicate about it</strong>. Every email is an opportunity to convert your inactive users to active users. When I go to their website, the first thing I see is that it's "Version control for designers." Include that in your email.

How relevant is the included image? It's a beautiful abstract drawing, but perhaps a screenshot of the product would be better.

Using a single call to action would make this email even simpler. It reduces the amount of decisions the reader has to make ("Which button should I click?"). Link to the "Learn more" page from the blog post.

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Customer Retention Email Design from Beats Music</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/retention/customer-retention-email-design-from-beats-music/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Apr 2014 09:14:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=1007</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>

	<item>
				<title>Welcome Email Design from Google Plus</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/welcome/welcome-email-design-from-google-plus/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 May 2014 03:18:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=1086</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
Getting started on Google+

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Welcome-Email-from-Google-Plus_Mobile.png"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Welcome-Email-from-Google-Plus_Mobile-305x1024.png" alt="Welcome-Email-from-Google-Plus_Mobile" width="305" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1087" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

Short and simple. Good use of whitespace and high contrast make the content very readable.

The email looks fun, mostly due to the Google colours at the bottom, which is consistent with Google's branding.

The content is relevant for a new user. Short descriptions tell you what you can do on Google+ and there are lots of links to the site.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

The header and footer hurt the overall appearance of the email, they could fit in better with the body. The Google+ logo in the header is grey, which is unusual. The content in the header and footer is left-aligned, while the body content is centred. The footer is very verbose, containing roughly the same amount of text as the body.

Some of the icons could be more appropriate. For example, a silhouette of a group of people for the first icon, and a mobile phone for the last icon.

The list of next steps comes across more as a list of selling points, but you're already sold if you just signed up. A numbered list would make it more obvious that it's a list of next steps to follow.

The links in those steps don't make sense on their own: "just the right people", "your photos", "Android", "iPhone". Make the links more descriptive by using the whole sentence as the link. It gives a better idea of what to expect when you click it, and is also friendlier for screen readers. And by having bigger clickable areas, click rates will likely increase.

The mobile view is way too narrow, but in this case I think the layout was responsive and the browser was resized incorrectly to take the screenshot. It's possible the email looks better on an actual phone.

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Daily Reminder Email Design from DuoLingo</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/transactional/daily-reminder-email-design-from-duolingo/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 May 2014 03:21:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=1090</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
Daily Spanish reminder email

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Daily-Reminder-Email-Design-from-DuoLingo_Mobile.png"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Daily-Reminder-Email-Design-from-DuoLingo_Mobile-351x1024.png" alt="Daily-Reminder-Email-Design-from-DuoLingo_Mobile" width="351" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1092" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

The design of this email focuses on simplicity. It's short and easy to read.

There's a lot of attention to detail. For example, the header includes an Inca temple, and the Inca Empire shares some history with Spanish (the language you happen to be learning).

People on the web usually skim through content looking for highlighted keywords, meaningful headings, short paragraphs and scannable lists. They're in a hurry and will skip what's irrelevant to them. The designers were aware of thatthe message is effectively communicated even if you were to scan through the email.

There's a good balance between text and images. Too much text makes an email lengthy and boring, most of it won't be read. Too many images makes the email appear spammy and cluttered; the email would also load slower, which is a big factor if you have a global audience like Duolingo does. Many people in the world are still on slow connections.

The email is focused: continue learning a language via Duolingo. To motivate you, a progress bar with a description indicates how far you are to the next level. With a goal in mind of reaching the next level, it's easy to get started because the call to action is the next thing you see.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

The subject "Daily Spanish reminder email" is entirely accurate, but not very engaging. I would delete the email without opening it if I were busy, because the subject does a good enough job of reminding me. Unfortunately it needs to do more than remind you. Do a few tests to experiment with different subject lines.

The progress section says how many points you're away from the next level, which doesn't tell me much. How do I get the points? How long will it take? Give me something I can understand. E.g. "133 points or ~2 lessons away from level 7".

The button text "Begin challenge" may be too intimidating. Could you get more conversions by making the task seem less risky? Or jumpstart the process by using the language you're learning as the button text. The hardest part to starting something is taking that first step, which they just did by reading the button in another language.

The layout isn't as nice in mobile view. The owl image is missing, yet the text is still left-aligned. The unsubscribe text can easily be reduced to two lines.

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>

[Harvest] Subscription Receipt

<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Receipt-Email-Design-from-Harvest_Mobile.png"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Receipt-Email-Design-from-Harvest_Mobile-441x400.png" alt="Receipt-Email-Design-from-Harvest_Mobile" width="230" height="208" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1095" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Promotional Email Design about Photos from Twitter</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/promotion/promotional-email-design-about-photos-from-twitter/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 12 May 2014 03:36:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=1108</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
Share your best photos on Twitter

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Promotional-Email-Design-about-Photos-from-Twitter_Mobile.png"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Promotional-Email-Design-about-Photos-from-Twitter_Mobile-330x1024.png" alt="Promotional-Email-Design-about-Photos-from-Twitter_Mobile" width="330" height="1024" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1112" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

I love this email. The photos make it engaging and tell a story, which is exactly what this email is trying to communicate.

The email is focused, all the features are related to photos. Introducing any more than three features would make the email too lengthy.

The wording is simple and the paragraphs are short. Each new feature includes a screenshot, making the features easier to understand.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

Not many. The alignment of the content seems a bit off, especially with the footer being centred.

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>NPS Score Survey Email Design from Squarespace</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/survey/nps-score-survey-email-design-from-squarespace/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 15 May 2014 02:42:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=1140</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
How are we doing?

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/NPS-Score-Survey-Email-Design-from-Squarespace_Mobile.png"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/NPS-Score-Survey-Email-Design-from-Squarespace_Mobile-174x400.png" alt="NPS-Score-Survey-Email-Design-from-Squarespace_Mobile" width="174" height="400" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1141" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

The email is focused on a single short task, getting feedback. No sales pitch, feature announcements, or any other distractions.

Getting feedback from users is always worthwhile. Lots of companies already send out similar emails, but they usually require you to go to some external survey. I typically delete such emails. This email on the other hand, makes the task very simple. I can quickly give feedback without leaving the email and I can immediately see that I don't have pages of questions to answer.

A greeting by name is always a nice personal touch. The subject line is incredibly simple and to the point.

The email uses a good amount of text and isn't littered with images. The most important text is bolded so it easily stands out from the lower contrast text.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

The email is bland and boring. Maybe using a cover photo for the header with the company logo overlaid could make it more interesting.

Even though the email does a great job at simplifying the process of giving feedback, it's still overly complicated.

The main question can be trimmed down to "How likely are you to recommend Squarespace?" which should nicely fit on one line.

The options scale is way too big. Too many choices leads us to stall and avoid choosing. What does option 2 mean for examplesomewhat unlikely? Narrow it down to about 3 choices (e.g. "Would not recommend", "Not sure", "Would recommend") and display them horizontally to make the email much shorter. Also make the clickable space more obvious by putting the options within borders, such as buttons.

The excessive thanks is redundant. The thanks at the bottom feels misdirected, being thanked for completing the form would make more sense at that point.

The links in the footer do not look like links. Links should be obvious.

Mobile view is a lot narrower, poorly aligning the logo in the header.

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Accepted Event Email Design from Sunrise</title>
		<link>http://reallygoodemails.com/transactional/accepted-event-email-design-from-sunrise/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 May 2014 04:34:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ChinPeiYew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://reallygoodemails.com/?p=1165</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
Accepted: lunch (Matt & Matthew) - Friday, May 16 @ 3:30pm

<h2>Mobile Email View</h2>
<a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Accepted-Event-Email-Design-from-Sunrise_Mobile.png"><img src="http://reallygoodemails.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Accepted-Event-Email-Design-from-Sunrise_Mobile.png" alt="Accepted-Event-Email-Design-from-Sunrise_Mobile" width="450" height="420" class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-1167" /></a>

<h3>Strengths</h3>

Incredibly short, no fluff. The email tells you what, when, and who. The important content stands out due to the colours and placement. The contrast against the light grey background works well.

The subject tells you the name of the event and when it's starting. It's an update <i>and</i> reminder without having to open the email.

Placing the update to the event"Matt Ayers is going"before all the other details make sense, because the goal of this email is to notify you that someone accepted your invitation. The other details are just reminders about the event.

The header and footer get out of the way of the content, but are still visible. The footer explains, very concisely, what the product isgreat for getting the word out to potential new users.

<h3>Weaknesses</h3>

It's not clear from the subject <i>who</i> accepted. Was it Matt or Matthew? This would be even more confusing if there were multiple invitations.

Where is the event? I'm not sure if this information was supplied and not included, or it's just never shown. But it sure is important.

The lunch symbol looks a bit dangerous. An X in a red circle doesn't tell me "lunch", especially if I were to glance at it. A standing knife and fork on their own would work much better. The icon is also much larger than the clock and people icons, and doesn't align well with its line.

"Matt Ayers is going." contains the only period in the email. Remove it to be consistent with the rest of the content.

It's difficult to tell who invited who. Based on the acceptance notification, you would think Matthew invited Matt. But the footer says that Matt is using Sunrise, which implies that he's the one that created the event on the calendar and therefore invited Matthew. Confusing!

How do I unsubscribe or change my notification preferences?

<sup>Commentary by <strong>Dennis Ideler</strong> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="http://reallygoodemails.com/?s=Dennis+Ideler" style="text-decoration: none;">View more commentary by Dennis</a> &nbsp;  &nbsp; <a href="https://twitter.com/dideler" style="text-decoration: none;">Follow Dennis on Twitter</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Email Subject</h2>
